habitat_description:
Spermophilus spilosoma inhabits sites with deep, sandy soils and sparse vegetation (Streubel and Fitzgerald, 1978; Fitzgerald et al., 1994). Habitats in which the species has been documented include: shinnery oak and mesquite grassland (Best et al., 1993); desert scrub creosote, blackbrush, prickly pear, mesquite, and/or yucca (Davis and Robertson, 1944; Whitford, 1976; Livoreil and Baudoin, 1993); grazed pasture (DeWitt Ivey, 1957; Streubel, 1975; Fleharty and Navo, 1983; Fitzgerald et al., 1994); sand sage prairie (Fleharty and Navo, 1983; Fitzgerald et al., 1994); sand dunes covered with grass and sandsage (McCampbell, 1926; Maxwell and Brown, 1968); short-grass mesas (DeWitt Ivey, 1957; Streubel and Fitzgerald, 1978); and along arroyos (DeWitt Ivey, 1957; Streubel and Fitzgerald, 1978). In Colorado, the species is most abundant in the northeastern sandhills (Fitzgerald et al., 1994).

The species is generally associated with bare ground percentages >40% (Maxwell and Brown, 1968; Streubel, 1975).

Elevations at which the spotted ground squirrel has been found range from near sea-level in Texas (Smith, 1973) to over 2100 m in Utah (Moore, 1930).
